child_demographics: Two children: B.H. (male, age 8), L.H. (female, age 6). B.H. diagnosed with high-functioning autism.
legal_issues_identified: Guardianship/Parenting Schedule (FLA s. 24); Reapportionment of Family Assets (FLA ss. 58, 65); Imputation of Income for Child/Spousal Support (FLA s. 18; Divorce Act s. 19 Guidelines); Retroactive Support Claims (D.B.S. v. S.R.G.).
summary_holding: Reapportionment of assets 65% to mother; phased parenting schedule with primary residence to mother; $1M income imputed to father for support.
winning_argument_type: Established pattern of non-compliance with best interests factors (FLA s. 24(1)(a)) + diminished earning capacity due to childcare sacrifice (Lodge v. Lodge)
failed_argument_type: Failed to meet burden of proof for retroactive support (D.B.S. v. S.R.G.) + lack of specific parenting plan accommodating special needs (Gordon v. Goertz)
judicial_disdain: I did not find [nanny] Ms. A. to be an unbiased witness. She receives significant personal benefits... luxury vehicle, travel (para. 73). Claimants reduced lifestyle assertions lack context (para. 210).
scc_precedent_applied: Y - Gordon v. Goertz (best interests/stability); Stein v. Stein (contingent liabilities); D.B.S. v. S.R.G. (retroactive support)
precedent_gap: None noted. Strict application of Gordon/Barendregt child-centric framework. Deviations justified by autism evidence (M.H.K.J. v. K.J.J.).
strategic_takeaway: Reapportionment under FLA s. 65(1)(e) requires nexus between childcare sacrifice and diminished earning capacity. High-income payors face formidable onus to avoid table amounts (Hollenbach).
counsels_analysis: ISSUE: Did the court properly apply FLA s. 65 reapportionment factors? RULE: Reapportionment requires unfairness finding per s. 65(1)(e)–(f). APPLICATION: Claimant proved 20-year career sacrifice and B.H.’s autism constraining economic independence. Respondent’s $4.7M post-separation home purchase demonstrated capacity. ANALYSIS GAP: Court ignored claimant’s $130K debt but offset by respondent’s tax liability allocation. CONCLUSION: 65% reapportionment legally sound. ISSUE: Was $1M income imputation justified? RULE: Guidelines s. 17 permits averaging volatile income. APPLICATION: Respondent’s $688K 2012 income outlier; $2.3M average overstated non-recurring gains. PREJUDICE: Imputation prevents manipulation via corporate structures (s. 18 Guidelines). CONCLUSION: $1M balances predictability/equity.
